interface.name: ATK-dev
interface.description: These are the ATK header files. They are required when compiling applications that use the ATK library. ATK is an Accessibility Toolkit.

interface.name: GLib-dev
interface.description: These are the GLib header files. They are required when compiling applications that use the GLib library.

interface.name: GLibmm-dev
interface.summary: headers for compiling C++ GLib applications
interface.description: These are the glibmm header files. They are required when compiling C++ applications that use the GLib library.

interface.name: GTK-2.4
interface.summary: set up a GTK 2.4 build environment
interface.description:
This program runs a command in an environment with PKG_CONFIG_PATH set to include the location of the GTK 2.4 and related library headers. By default, it runs /bin/sh to give you a shell.
Typical usage is to run this and then configure and build your program from the new shell. The resulting binary should work on all systems with GTK 2.4 and later.
Note: if you build your program using Zero Install then it's easier to just add the GTK dependencies to the source interface file.

interface.name: GTK-dev
interface.description: These are the GTK header files. They are required when compiling applications that use the GTK+ library.

interface.name: GTKmm-dev
interface.summary: headers for compiling C++ GTK applications
interface.description: These are the glibmm header files. They are required when compiling C++ applications that use the GTK, ATK or Pango libraries..

interface.name: Pango-dev
interface.description: These are the Pango header files. They are required when compiling applications that use the Pango library. Pango is a library for laying out and rendering of text, with an emphasis on internationalization.

interface.name: ZeroInstall-GUI
interface.summary: graphical interface for the Zero Install injector
interface.description: The Zero Install GUI displays a window showing which versions of various components will be used when running a program, and allows you to alter various policy settings to affect the selection process. You can use this to mark particular versions of libraries as preferred, bugggy, etc.
